awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Integration of Computational Thinking into Preservice Elementary Science Teacher Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to advance multidisciplinary integration of computing in STEM teaching and learning through applied research and development across one or more domains. This project addresses the challenge of how to prepare undergraduate elementary preservice science teachers to learn methods involved in computational thinking (CT) in order to support integration of CT into their elementary STEM instruction. Such early integration of CT in STEM learning will provide the foundation that young children need in computational thinking when their interests and competencies are being formed. Additionally, early integration of CT in STEM may increase the number and diversity of students interested in enrolling in high school computer science courses (and thus in computer science careers). The first step is to improve the preparation that elementary teachers receive about CT to increase both the quantity and quality of exposure for elementary-aged children. The overall goal of this project, therefore, is to transform elementary school teacher practice by integrating CT strategically and significantly into science instruction for all young learners, thereby promoting a more numerous and more diverse citizenry that is knowledgeable and interested in computing. Findings and materials from this project will be disseminated to a broad group of stakeholders, including policymakers, researchers, teacher educators, and K-12 personnel and community.

This project will address the fundamental question, "What strategies are most effective in integrating computational thinking effectively into elementary preservice teachers' pedagogical preparation experiences in science in order to cultivate and improve access to CT for all students?" The project team will design, implement, and test pedagogical modules for developing CT in a preservice teachers' science methods pedagogical course. Further, an extracurricular Science Teaching CT Inquiry Group will be designed to enhance and broaden the level of understanding of CT for both teacher interns and their mentor teachers, including how computer applications support the teaching of science and how CT is a necessary science practice for all elementary-aged students. This inquiry group will be led by an interdisciplinary team with a variety of expertise, including computer scientists, science educators, educational technologists, and graduates of the elementary education program (during the 2nd year of the project). Instruction in how to convey to young learners the integral nature of CT for STEM career awareness and readiness will be included throughout the curriculum innovation. Because this study will use a design-based methodology, design and testing of the resources and measures will be conducted cyclically and concurrently. This  program of research will use a rigorous mixed methods research approach to collect both qualitative and quantitative data that will be triangulated to develop and analyze resources, measures, and processes. As such, this project seeks to engage in exploratory, basic research to provide empirical support in developing a set of resources (science methods experiences), tools (a framework for integrating CT in undergraduate science teacher pedagogy education), and measures (assessments for CT understanding and CT STEM career awareness).

por.por_cntn:
Our project explored how the practices of computation thinking (CT), which originate in computer science but are useful and important concepts and processes that can be used to solve a wide range of problems (Wing, 2006; Grover and Pea, 2013), could be best integrated into elementary science lessons. Researchers and policymakers argue that CT is central to participating in an increasingly computational workforce and society and should therefore be integrated into existing subjects within K-12 education (Lee & Malyn-Smith, 2020; National Science and Technology Council, 2018).

 We first worked with university students, studying to be elementary teachers (pre-service teachers). We investigated what they thought of the different CT practices and which ones they found most useful in elementary science lessons. From this work, we determined multiple design lessons for teaching CT to pre-service teachers, including the importance of giving opportunities to both engage in and apply CT practices through CT tools like robots, simulations, citizen science data collection, and simple computer programming.

 We next designed a professional development (PD) experience that in-service teachers and pre-service teachers could take together. We ran this PD experience twice. The first year we tested many of the same ideas we had explored with the university students. However, within the PD, teachers were able to use those ideas to develop lessons that they could then test out for themselves in their classrooms. We analyzed what worked best from year one to redesign the PD in year two. For year two, we merged our learning from year one to develop a CT for elementary science framework, focusing on the four CT practices that analysis demonstrated teachers and students found most useful when integrating CT into elementary science: Using Data, Programming, Computational Simulations, and Systems Thinking from a Computational Perspective. See Figure 1. 

 We found that in the second year of the redesigned PD experience, teachers were much better at understanding and integrating CT practices. In year one, teachers often relied on using data practices to integrate CT into the elementary science lessons, but they often weren’t collecting data in a way that emphasized CT. We also found that the redesigned PD structure maximized collaborations between in-service, pre-service and researchers to build and share knowledge in powerful ways.

 We emphasized the importance of integrating CT into science lessons for all students. However, some of our teacher participants shared that they felt CT was best suited for certain students (for example high-performing students or those already interested in computing) rather than for all. This finding pushed our research group to extend our project to explore how to help teachers learn how to teach CT for all students. In this final year, we partnered with a university instructor to explore how undergraduate students might develop CT-integrated elementary science lessons through a culturally responsive lens. We wanted to understand how CT, culturally responsive teaching, and elementary science concepts intertwine as well as explore how the three ideas could be taught integratively to pre-service elementary teachers. Our research showed that CT and culturally responsive teaching can be designed and taught in elementary science classrooms, but that teaching all three together requires intensive reflection by the instructor. Through this reflection, the instructor was able to see how CT applied to elementary science education and gradually learned how to teach CT while including culturally responsive teaching practices.

 Our project has increased understanding of how to best integrate CT into elementary classrooms by looking specifically at elementary science as a way to reach all students. We have worked with pre-service university students, their professors, and in-service teachers to increase understanding of what CT practices are, and how particular practices can be successfully integrated into science lessons. We have also shared our findings with other researchers that are thinking about CT.  Our research team has published 11 journal papers and presented at 16 academic conferences in the fields of science education, computer science education, and equitable education. We have also shared our design insights with professionals that design and implement PD experiences via a live, virtually delivered 3-hour workshop for international science educators and researchers. Lastly, we have designed a public website that offers our detailed project material for use by teachers and teacher educators (https://education.umd.edu/research/centers/cste/research/integrating-computational-thinking-preservice-elementary-science).
